you don't edit grub.cfg
run:  gksudo gedit /etc/default/grub     and add it in the quotes with: quiet splash   then run: sudo update-grub
its old or wrong, the grub.cfg file is generated when you run: update-grub   or when a new kernel is added (which then reruns the same command)
so you add it in /etc/default/grub  then run: sudo update-grub   this will apply the new boot option to the standing kernels as well as future kernels
after you add the option, run: sudo update-grub  then mbr is untouched but the grub config is updated
np dude
you add the boot option in the quotes, so if you want to disable ipv6, you can change: GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX_DEFAULT="quiet splash"   to: GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX_DEFAULT="quiet splash ipv6.disable=1"
you don't just add stuff because the whim takes you, the boot options are to achieve a goal
the amount of space it uses is minimal, why not just leave it?
